com.link_intersystems.beans.java

Class JavaProperty

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.link_intersystems.beans.java.JavaProperty
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Property, Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JavaIndexedProperty

    public class JavaProperty
extends Object
implements Serializable, Property
    Encapsulates access to a java bean property. 
     public class SomeBean {

    private String internalName;

    public void setName(String name){
      this.internalName = name;
    }

    public String getName(){
        return internalName;
    }

 }

 ...
 SomeBean someBean = new SomeBean();

 Bean bean = new Bean();
 Property nameProp = bean.getProperty("name");
 nameProp.setValue("Hello");

 assertEquals("Hello", someBean.getName());
    Since:
    1.2.0;
    Author:
    Ren√© Link [rene.link@link- intersystems.com]

    the JavaProperty's type.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getValue

        public <T> T getValue()
        Gets the value of this JavaProperty.
        Specified by:
        getValue in interface Property
        Returns:
        the value of this property.
        Throws:
        PropertyReadException - if the property could not be accessed for any reason. If the thrown PropertyReadException has no cause this property is not readable (has no property getter method).
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • setValue

        public void setValue(Object propertyValue)
        Sets the value of this JavaProperty.
        Specified by:
        setValue in interface Property
        Parameters:
        propertyValue - the value to set.
        Throws:
        PropertyReadException - if this JavaProperty's value could not be set. If the thrown PropertyWriteException has no cause this property is not writable (has no property setter method).
        Since:
        1.2.0;

      • getDeclaringClass

        public Class<?> getDeclaringClass()
        The declaring class of a JavaProperty is the class that first mentions the property. So it can be either the read or write method's declaring class. If the read and write methods are defined in different classes the uppermost class in the hierarchy is returned.
